lines.text: I never doubted he'd do as well as anyone else.
Where he's concerned, you never doubted, period. If he came in right now and said he could fly, you'd help him out the window.
In all my life, the past twelve hours are the only real freedom I've ever known.
Did you enjoy it?
Every moment.
Why did you come back?
I'm a coward.
Bless us and save us, said Mrs. O'Davis.
Joy, joy, said Mrs. Malloy.
Mercy, mercy, said old Mrs. Percy.
You know, it's one of the big regrets of my life I was never in the service?
I know.
The day World War One was declared, I went to the recruiting office. When they learned I was the sole support of the family, they turned me down.
I know.
I would have gone to the Front!
I'm sure of that.
But once there, how would I have done?
Fine.
How do you know?
You're a born fighter.
But they say a lot of guys who were terrors as civilians turned to jelly when they heard those bullets.
Not you.
Well, doesn't seem so... but you can't be sure. See, that's always bothered me.
Hurry up with your breakfast.
What for?
Mass starts in twenty minutes, you're not even dressed.
Mass?
Mass.
I haven't been to Mass in over three years. You know that.
Lots of bad habits you boys picked up you'll have to get over.
Not going to Mass isn't a habit I picked up. It's a decision I came to after a lot of thought.
Now, what way is *that* for a Catholic to talk?
I haven't considered myself a Catholic for quite a while.

[Looks at his son, slightly dumbfounded]
There must be something wrong with my ears.
So you've outgrown the Faith, huh?
Well, it doesn't answer my needs...
Outgrown your old clothes, and outgrown the Faith.
Pop, will you listen to me, please?
Millions of people have believed in it since the beginning of time, but it's not *good* enough for you.
It's not a question of "good enough".
Well, what do you say, when people ask you what religion you are?

[pauses to reflect]
Nothing.

[Showing disgust]
You say you're "nothing".
Yes.
The Clearys have been Catholics since... since the beginning of time. And now you, a Cleary, are going to tell people you're a "nothing"?
Yes.
You're an atheist!
I'm not an atheist.
What are you?
I don't know, but I'd like a chance to find out.
You don't know what you believe in?
Do you?
Yes!
Tell me. Go on...
I believe in the Father, the Son and the Holy Ghost. I believe God created Man in his own image...

[Interrupting]
Pop! If your faith works for you, I'm glad. Really, I'm very glad. I wish it worked for me, but it doesn't.
Do you believe in God - yes or no?
I don't believe in heaven or hell or purgatory...

[Interrupting, shouting]
YES or NO!
I believe there is something bigger than myself. What you call it or what it is, I don't know.

[Looking disgusted]
Well, this is a fine how-do-you-do.

[Calmly]
Yesterday you said he was a man. A man has a right to decide such things for himself.
